Guide to the Laura Foreman Papers
1949-2001
MSS 122

physdesc.extent: (122 records cartons, 27 photo binders, 2 document cases and 5 oversize boxes)

did.abstract: Laura Foreman was a dancer, choreographer, visual artist, writer and director of dance at New School University. She lived and worked in New York City from the mid-1960s until her death. Material in the Laura Foreman Papers related to Foreman's art includes project notes, sketches and drafts, photographic and audiovisual documentation, grant applications, props, art objects, and press clippings. Material related to Foreman's personal life includes correspondence, personal notes, journals, and appointment books. The collection also contains course planning materials and administrative files related to Foreman's career at the New School.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Laura Foreman Papers; MSS 122; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Laura Foreman was a dancer, choreographer, visual artist, writer and director of dance at New School University. She lived and worked in New York City from the mid-1960s until her death.
Foreman worked primarily in dance for the first decade of her time in Manhattan, operating both the Laura Foreman Dance Company and Composers' and Choreographers' Theatre with her husband, John Watts. In the late 1970s she began working in more abstract performance and visual art. Perhaps her most well-known piece was 1981's "Wallwork," a collaboration with Watts which took the form of a rigorous advertising campaign for a nonexistent performance.
After Watts's death in 1982, Foreman's work shifted towards visual art and writing. She created an extensive sculpture series, "Birdhouse as Metaphor," which consisted of numerous functional and non-functional birdhouses and showed in 1990 at Souyun Yi Gallery. In 1997, Close Encounters, a volume of Foreman's short stories, was published by Outloud Books.
Foreman died of cancer in Manhattan in 2001.
Source:
Dunning, Jennifer. "Laura Foreman, 64, Director Of Dance at the New School." The New York Times, July 5, 2001.
Stage Works:
- Solo Suite (1967)
- A Time (1968)
- Perimeters (1969)
- Untitled (1970)
- Epicycles (1970)
- Signals (1970)
- glass and shadows (1971)
- Laura's Dance (1971)
- Songandance (1972)
- Margins (1972)
- Spaces (1972)
- Locrian (1973)
- Performance (1973)
- city of angels (1974)
- a deux (1974)
- Postludes (1974)
- Bud / Monopoly (1975)
- Program (1976)
- Heirlooms (1977)
- Entries (1978)
Artworks:
- TimeCoded Woman (1979-80)
- Coney Island Cray-Pas (1981)
- Philadelphia Story (1981)
- Poetry Peep Show (1981)
- Roomwork (1981)
- Wallwork (1981)
- Reclining Nudes (1982)
- Sweet Land of Liberty (1983)
- Word Painting / I have nothing to paint and I'm painting it (1983)
- Birdhouse as Metaphor (1989-93)
- Cry Uncle (1991)
- Window on the World (1995)
- Shacks of America (undated)
Written Works:
- A Message to Michael (1990)
- Close Encounters (1997)

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged almost entirely as they were received. The collection was processed at the box level; a description of contents is given for each box. These descriptions are in no way comprehensive. See the Arrangement Notes for each series for more specific details. Loose items and those in need of special preservation attention were appropriately housed, and all efforts were made to preserve the collection's original arrangement.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The collection was donated to the Fales Library by Laura Foreman in 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Laura Foreman Papers contain materials pertaining to Foreman's life as a dancer, choreographer, visual and performance artist, as well as her personal life and career as Director of the Dance Department at the New School. Material related to Foreman's works includes project notes, sketches and drafts, photographic and audiovisual documentation, grant applications, props, art objects, and press clippings. Material related to Foreman's personal life includes correspondence, personal notes, journals, and appointment books. The collection also contains course planning materials and administrative files related to Foreman's career at the New School. Items in the collection date as far back as 1949, but the bulk of the collection covers a range from 1967 until Foreman's death in 2001.
The collection is divided into eight series:
SERIES I: Files contains documents and items related to Foreman's personal life and artistic career, including project drafts, personal notes, source material and press clippings.
SERIES II: Notebooks, Address Books and Date Books contains bound notebooks relating to Foreman's personal and artistic life, as well as originally collocated notecards.

SERIES III: Correspondence contains correspondence, primarily addressed to Foreman and dealing mostly with her personal life. A small portion of the correspondence pertains to her professional and artistic life.

SERIES IV: Photographic Material contains photographic prints, color slides, contact sheets and negatives pertaining both to Foreman's personal life and to her work as a choreographer and visual artist.
SERIES V: Artworks, Sketches and Posters contains primarily visual material produced by Foreman, including sketches, drafts, and posters from her own as well as others' performances and exhibitions.

SERIES VI: Video contains Foreman's collection of video documentation of her dance performances and other artworks and exhibitions.
Subseries A: Access Copies
Subseries B: Originals

SERIES VII: Film contains a small amount of moving image documentation captured on film instead of video.
Subseries A: Access Copies
Subseries B: Originals

SERIES VIII: Audio contains audio recordings.
Subseries A: Access Copies
Subseries B: Originals
SERIES IX: Objects contains various items once owned by Foreman or employed in her artworks, including props from dance performances.

OVERSIZE SERIES includes materials too large to be stored in a records carton or photo binder.
Series I: Files
Series IV: Photographic Material
Series V: Artworks, Sketches and Posters

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p:
The following materials have been removed to Fales Downtown Collection, Fales Special Collections and Fales American Collection:
Art now 74: a celebration of the American arts. Washington, D.C.: Artrend Foundation, 1974.
The comics journal. Vol. 111. Bethel, CT: Comics Journal, 1986.
Downtown. No. 40. New York, N.Y.: Arts Weekly, 1987.
Foreman, Laura. Close encounters: a book of short stories. Claryville, N.Y.: Outloud Books, 1997.
Fujimura, Makoto. Makoto Fujimura: works '90-'92. Tokyo: Tamaya Gallery, 1992.
Fujimura, Makoto, and International Arts Movement. Wouldest thou love.... New York, N.Y.: International Arts Movement, c1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Series I contains general files, mostly from Foreman's personal hanging file. The contents of this series relate to nearly all facets of Foreman's life and work.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement note
scopecontent.p: All efforts were made to preserve the original arrangement of the collection. Series I is described at the box level, with a listing of the types of files that are ostensibly contained within. These file types, generated by the finding aid author, are as follows:

Administrative Materials
Documentation
Drafts
Financial Files
Grant Materials
Outlines
Personal Files
Press
Production Files
Publishers’ Files
Source Material
Teaching Materials

Each file type is annotated parenthetically when it pertains to a specific medium or organization. Each box is then annotated, when applicable, with a list of specific works that are referenced within the materials in the box (see Biographical Note for list of works).

did.unittitle: Series II: Notebooks, Address Books and Date Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Series II contains notebooks, address books, date books and bundled notecards found loose during the processing of the collection. The contents range from performance notes, to daily planners, to personal memoranda.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement note
scopecontent.p: The contents of this series are arranged chronologically. A great deal of the notebooks and cards are undated; these are housed at the end of the series, grouped together as found.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Series III contains correspondence, most of which was written to Foreman by her mother, Gladys Foreman. In addition to personal correspondence, a small portion of this series pertains to Foreman's art, writing and teaching.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement note
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged chronologically, with an emphasis on preserving Foreman's original arrangement. Because original arrangement was the main processing concern, there are small chronological overlaps from folder to folder (e.g. a folder dated "1986-89" may be followed by one dated "1987-88"). There is no chronological overlap between boxes in the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: The photographic material of Series IV spans the entirety of Foreman's career, from early dance performances through later art installations in the nineteen-nineties. Performances from the Laura Foreman Dance Company are very well documented, as are the numerous derivations of Foreman's "Birdhouse as Metaphor" series. Photographers of Foreman's dance performances include Robert Alexander, Peter Moore and Milton Oleaga.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement note
scopecontent.p: The photographic material is arranged thematically and chronologically, similarly to the list of works in the Biographical Note above. Stage works are documented first, followed by artworks, followed by specific installations and exhibitions, and concluding with personal and unidentified photos. Each box is annotated with the photographic processes contained within.

did.unittitle: Series V: Artworks, Sketches and Posters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Series V contains primarily visual material produced by Foreman, including sketches, drafts, and posters from her own as well as others' performances and exhibitions.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement note
scopecontent.p: The materials in Series V are arranged alphabetically by folder title. The majority of the works are untitled. Where posssible, entire sketchbooks are housed intact. Otherwise, materials remain in their original arrangements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Series VI contains Foreman's collection of video documentation of her dance performances and other artworks and exhibitions.

scopecontent.head: Conditions Governing Use
scopecontent.p: Access copies may not be available. Please consult a Fales archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Series IX contains various items once owned by Foreman or employed in her artworks, including props from dance performances.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement note
scopecontent.p: The objects in Series IX are arranged thematically, if rather loosely. Every object has its own identification number. The first objects listed are those that pertain to Foreman's dance career. Those that were difficult to align with any part of Foreman's career follow.

did.unittitle: Photographic Print - unidentified event, mounted on foam core and 11x14 card
Choreographers Theatre button; reads "Modern Dance Power"
Costume worn by Satoru Shimazaki in Entries
Large copper bell on a long, multi-colored beaded necklace
Six copper bells and multi-colored beads tied on a leather string
Five small copper bells tied on an orange rope; label attached reads "Camel Bells"
Five small gold bells tied on an orange rope
Two small gold bells tied on an orange rope
Thin orange, green and white rope tied in a bow
Ziploc bag containing four keys; marked "Play Keys"
Plastic zipper case containing CCT Corporate Seal Embosser
Composers and Choreographers Theatre Corporate Seal Embosser
Medal in case, from International Film and TV Festival of New York
"Dancing Finger Bear" toy, in original packaging

Small knitted kite made of yarn and two popsicle sticks
